title: "COVID-19 Drive Through Testing: An Effective Strategy for Conserving Personal Protective Equipment".
text: "COVID-19 Drive Through Testing: An Effective Strategy for Conserving Personal Protective Equipment".

similar.title: Electronic Personal Protective Equipment: A Strategy to Protect Emergency Department Providers in the Age of COVID-19.
text: Electronic Personal Protective Equipment: A Strategy to Protect Emergency Department Providers in the Age of COVID-19.

Emergent policy changes related to telemedicine and the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA) during the novel coronavirus pandemic (COVID-19) have created opportunities for technology-based clinical evaluation, which serves to conserve personal protective equipment (PPE) and protect emergency providers. We define electronic personal protective equipment (ePPE) as an approach using telemedicine tools to perform electronic medical screening exams while satisfying EMTALA. We discuss the safety, legal, and technical factors necessary for implementing such a pathway. This approach has the potential to conserve PPE and protect providers while maintaining safe standards for medical screening exams in the ED for low risk patients in whom COVID-19 is suspected.

We define electronic personal protective equipment (ePPE) as an approach using telemedicine tools to perform electronic medical screening exams while satisfying EMTALA. We discuss the safety, legal, and technical factors necessary for implementing such a pathway. This approach has the potential to conserve PPE and protect providers while maintaining safe standards for medical screening exams in the ED for low risk patients in whom COVID-19 is suspected.

similar.title: Covid-19: the crisis of personal protective equipment in the US.

similar.title: Testing for coverage from personal protective equipment: Public Health England's guidance does not protect healthcare workers from droplet spray.
text: Testing for coverage from personal protective equipment: Public Health England's guidance does not protect healthcare workers from droplet spray.

In order to reduce transmission of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, healthcare workers in the UK are advised to wear personal protective equipment (PPE). When undertaking aerosol-generating procedures, Public Health England recommends the use of gloves, gown, filtering mask and full-face visor or goggles . Despite this, uncertainty remains regarding the role of some items of PPE, such as hoods and visors .
